Question: file comparison with memory consideration: :I want to compare two files, one is in file system and the other is being downloaded from a HTTP URL. We have tried to compare by byte[] arrays (we used HTTPRequestBuilder by Apache), but the concern is that the files may be too large and they may exhaust the memory. Do we have any good alternates.
Please using this api: InputStream.read.
Answer: <<<api>>>: InputStream.read
<<<code>>>: 
```java
import java.io.*;
import java.net.*;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
        URL url1 = new URL("http://example.com/file1.txt");
        URL url2 = new URL("file:///path/to/file2.txt");

        InputStream in1 = url1.openStream();
        FileInputStream in2 = new FileInputStream(new File(url2.toURI()));

        byte[] buffer1 = new byte[1024];
        byte[] buffer2 = new byte[1024];

        int bytesRead1;
        int bytesRead2;

        while ((bytesRead1 = in1.read(buffer1)) != -1 && (bytesRead2 = in2.read(buffer2)) != -1) {
            if (bytesRead1 != bytesRead2 || !Arrays.equals(buffer1, buffer2)) {
                System.out.println("Files are different");
                return;
            }
        }

        System.out.println("Files are the same");
    }
}
```
<<<explanation>>>: This code reads the files in chunks of 1024 bytes (you can adjust this size as needed) and compares the chunks. If the chunks are not the same or the number of bytes read from each stream is different, it prints "Files are different". If it reads the same number of bytes and the chunks are the same, it prints "Files are the same". This approach is memory-efficient because it only keeps the current chunk in memory, not the entire file.

Note: This code assumes that the files are accessible via HTTP and the file system, respectively. If the files are not accessible in this way, you will need to adjust the code to read from the files in a different way.
